Literature Review: Public health surveillance is a cornerstone of effective public health practice, providing the data necessary for the early detection of outbreaks, the monitoring of disease trends, and the evaluation of public health interventions. The national notifiable disease reporting system (NNDRS) serves as a critical infrastructure for this purpose, enabling the systematic collection, analysis, and dissemination of health data. However, the COVID-19 pandemic has underscored both the strengths and limitations of current surveillance systems, highlighting the need for technological innovations to enhance their effectiveness. This literature review explores the evolution of public health surveillance, with a focus on emerging infections, and examines the role of new technologies in transforming surveillance practices. The traditional NNDRS has been instrumental in tracking infectious diseases, but its reliance on manual data entry and reporting can lead to delays and inaccuracies. Studies have shown that the timeliness and completeness of data are critical for effective disease control, yet many systems struggle to meet these standards (Smith et al., 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has further exposed these challenges, with rapid case escalation overwhelming existing surveillance capacities (Jones et al., 2021). In response, there has been a push towards integrating advanced technologies into public health surveillance. Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and spatial modeling have emerged as powerful tools for visualizing disease spread and identifying high-risk areas. By mapping cases in real-time, public health officials can allocate resources more efficiently and implement targeted interventions (Brown et al., 2019). Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning algorithms offer the potential to predict outbreaks before they occur, by analyzing patterns in large datasets that would be impossible for humans to process manually (Taylor et al., 2020). These technologies can also improve the accuracy of case reporting, by automating the detection of anomalies and inconsistencies in data. Information technology and data science are playing an increasingly important role in public health surveillance, enabling the integration of diverse data sources and the development of more comprehensive disease models. The digital twin method, which creates virtual replicas of physical systems, is being explored as a way to simulate disease spread and test the impact of different intervention strategies (Wilson et al., 2021). These innovations promise to enhance the timeliness, completeness, and accuracy of surveillance data, providing public health officials with the information they need to respond more effectively to emerging infections. However, the adoption of these technologies also raises ethical and privacy concerns, particularly regarding the collection and use of personal health data. Ensuring the security of surveillance systems and protecting the privacy of individuals will be critical as these technologies become more widespread (Harris et al., 2020). In conclusion, the integration of advanced technologies into public health surveillance offers the potential to transform the way we detect, monitor, and respond to infectious diseases. By improving the accuracy and timeliness of data, these innovations can enhance our ability to prevent and control outbreaks, ultimately saving lives. However, careful consideration must be given to the ethical implications of these technologies, to ensure that they are used in a way that respects individual rights and promotes public trust.
